page.title: 18COUNTRYSIDE
page.content: Many people enjoy country pursuits such as riding, hunting and shooting, both game and vermin. Bird watching and nature study are encouraged at school and a pony club appeals to young riders. Many households have dogs and walking is popular over the many footpaths and bridleways. Rabbits are increasing and there are badgers, foxes, stoats and other wild fauna. Wild flowers have decreased with the ploughing up and improvement of downland, but bluebells and cowslips survive. Elms are dead, but beech, oak and sycamore survive on the clay tops. Cherries, plums, sloes, blackberries and mushrooms can be had from the hedgerows. The balance between conservation, agriculture and new development is much discussed, part- icularly where new building or tree felling is proposed
